body: @junit-team/junit-lambda, let's discuss the merits of this proposal.

I think I tried that but it didn't work because of a few resource bundles inside the jopt-simple jar that contain class names. We would have to process those as well, but I couldn't find a suitable post-processor at the time.
In that case, the [Shadow Plugin](https://github.com/johnrengelman/shadow) may be a better choice than [jarjar](https://code.google.com/archive/p/jarjar/).

@sbrannen, if the Shadow Plugin and jarjar don't work, may I recommend trying [Capsule](https://github.com/puniverse/capsule)? I've personally used it in the past, and it seems to produce nice executable JARs even for large-ish projects. Although it doesn't have any official build tool plugins, the website does point to some third-party ones including for Gradle (http://www.capsule.io/user-guide/#build-tool-plugins).

Hmm, then again, I don't know if Capsule can be used for renaming library classes and all references to those classes. I'd still recommend having a look at it, however, if all your other options fail.
@jbduncan, thanks for the tip. If all else fails, we'll look into Capsule.

As far as I can tell, the _Shadow Plugin_ does not have a built-in `Transformer` that will rename the class name based property keys in JOpt Simple's properties files.

However, it should be simple enough to create our own custom transformer for that purpose, and we can use the [PropertiesFileTransformer](https://github.com/johnrengelman/shadow/blob/master/src/main/groovy/com/github/jengelman/gradle/plugins/shadow/transformers/PropertiesFileTransformer.groovy) for inspiration.

issue.title: Should there be a repository for "official" JUnit 5 extensions

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Many JUnit 5 Extensions will be lightweight glue code that connect two disparate projects.  Examples include the MockitoExtension and the JUnitParamsExtension (which is part of my AfterDiscoveryCallback PoC).  Other Extensions will replace existing JUnit 4 @Rules, such as the TemporaryFolder rule.  This class of extensions logically are only dependent upon JUnit 4.

Would it make sense to create a junit5-extensions project (repository) where members of the various project communities could collaborate?  When posed to the Mockito team in issue https://github.com/mockito/mockito/issues/438#issuecomment-227016382, @TimvdLippe suggested that the JUnit 5 team be asked.

issue.body:
The `shadowJar` task takes care of merging service files.
This task will generate an artifact with "all" as classifier;
this artifact is not yet configured for publication to a maven
compatible repository.
